title: My Weird Lavender Tallow Balm: The Beef Fat That Fixed My Winter Face
body:
Okay so I’m just gonna say it. I put beef fat on my face. I know. It sounds like something you’d do on a dare in college, or like, a weird historical thing your great-grandma did. My friend Sam literally said “you’re putting what on your face?” when I told her. She made a face. I get it. Beef tallow skincare? Sounds like you’re prepping a steak, not a skincare routine. But here’s the thing—my skin was a disaster this winter. Flaky, tight, angry. Like a dried-up riverbed. I tried the expensive stuff, the stuff in the fancy jars that cost more than my electric bill. Nothing. So I was scrolling Etsy one night, it was late, like 1 AM, and I saw this whipped tallow balm. Lavender scent. I was skeptical. So skeptical. But I was also desperate. And my cat, Mango, was judging me from the arm of the couch. So I bought it.

Anyway. It showed up a couple weeks later in this little jar. I opened it. Smelled like lavender. Not like a candle, but like… real lavender? And something else. Something earthy. I don’t know. It was soft. Like, really soft. I poked it. The texture was weird. Good weird. Like cool butter but fluffier. I stared at it for a good minute. “This is beef fat,” I said out loud to my empty living room. The neighbor’s TV was on too loud. I took a breath and just went for it.

## How I Started Putting Tallow on My Face (And Why It’s Not Gross)

Look. I had to google “is tallow good for skin” like five times before I actually put it on. My brain kept going to cooking. Roast potatoes. Pie crust. Not my cheeks. But the more I read, the less weird it sounded. This stuff—grass-fed beef tallow, specifically—is apparently really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So the idea is it doesn’t just sit on top like a plastic wrap. It gets it. It’s like giving your skin something it actually recognizes. Which, when you think about it, makes way more sense than slathering on a bunch of unpronounceable chemicals from a lab. We’ve been using animal fats in skincare forever. Lard, tallow, all that. My grandma probably did it. She had great skin.

So that first night, I washed my face, patted it dry, and scooped a tiny bit. It melted the second it touched my skin. Like, instantly. No tugging, no greasy film. It just… vanished. But my face felt different. Not oily. Not sticky. Just… quiet. Calm. I went to bed smelling like a lavender field and feeling vaguely like a pioneer woman. In a good way.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does (Besides Confuse Your Friends)

I didn’t expect much. Honestly. I thought maybe it’d be a nice moisturizer. That’s it. But the beef tallow balm benefits started showing up in weird little ways. After a few days, I noticed the little dry patches by my eyebrows were just… gone. Not covered up. Gone. My foundation stopped clinging to every flake. Then my hands. I’m a compulsive hand-washer, always have been, and in winter they crack and bleed. It’s awful. I started using the leftover balm on my knuckles. The rough, red skin smoothed out in like, two nights. I was shocked.

The lavender part is no joke either. It’s not a perfume-y scent. It’s herbal. Straight-up. It smells like calm. I started using it as my last step before bed, and I swear it signals to my brain that it’s time to shut off. The whole ritual—the smell, the feeling—it’s like a sleep aid in a jar. My anxiety before bed, that whole racing-thoughts thing, it just… eases. I don’t know how else to explain it. It’s become my non-negotiable night cream. I got mine from this little shop on Etsy that makes it in France, and the whole thing feels kind of special. Not luxury-brand special, but like, carefully-made special.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of Beef Fat

So it’s been a couple months now. I’m on my second jar. I keep it on my nightstand. The results are… they’re simple. My skin isn’t “glowing” in that Instagram way. It’s just healthy. It doesn’t hurt when I smile because it’s so tight. The fine lines around my eyes—the ones I’d stare at in the magnifying mirror—look less like cracks and more like just… my face. It’s plumper. Hydrated from the inside out. I used to have this expensive cream in a silver jar that did nothing but smell nice. This stuff in the simple glass jar actually works.

And my elbows! God, my elbows haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid. I just rub whatever’s left on my fingers on them. It’s become this whole thing. My mom visited, saw the jar, and I gave her the whole spiel. She was skeptical too. Now she texts me asking for the link. It’s that kind of product. You try it as a joke, then you realize it’s not a joke at all.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. Absolutely. Without a second thought. The weirdness factor is gone. Now it’s just my balm. When people ask what I use on my skin, I tell them. I watch the confusion flash across their face, and then I explain. Most of them get curious. A few have ordered it. Everyone who’s tried it has said the same thing: “Wow, it actually works.” That’s the whole story. It just works. I don’t have a science degree. I can’t tell you the molecular structure of tallow. All I know is my skin was screaming, and this quieted it down. It feels like a secret, but it shouldn’t be.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it really is. Especially if you have dry or sensitive skin. Since it’s so similar to our own skin’s oils, it absorbs deep and doesn’t just sit there clogging stuff up. It’s like giving your skin back what the winter air (and modern life) steals from it.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I’m prone to clogged pores. It’s non-comedogenic, which is a fancy way of saying it shouldn’t clog them. It melts right in. If anything, my skin feels more balanced—less oily in the day because it’s not freaking out and over-producing oil to compensate for being dry.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Like real lavender. Not candy or soap. It’s herbal, a little earthy, and honestly just really calming. It’s not overpowering. It fades to a soft scent after a few minutes. It’s the main reason I use it at night—it just sets a relaxing mood.

Anyway. If your skin’s being difficult, or you’re just curious about this whole beef tallow skincare thing… might be worth a shot. It’s one of the few things that’s actually lived up to the hype for me. I’m probably gonna order another one soon. Just in case.
